question: Good place to send money home?
ground_truth: Automated Remittance Kiosk Use authorised remittance kiosks located in dormitories or at a recreation centre Unlicensed remittance agents such as hawala or hundi brokers may run away with your money. Online Remittance Websites and Mobile Apps Use only licensed online remittance services and mobile apps. Never send money home through WhatsApp or any instant messaging platforms. Check if the remittance company is licensed by searching their name on Monetary Authority of Singapore’s website at https://eservices.mas.gov.sg/fid.
answer: It is recommended to use authorized remittance kiosks located in dormitories or at a recreation centre for sending money home safely. Online remittance websites and mobile apps from licensed online remittance services can also be used, but never send money home through WhatsApp or any instant messaging platforms. Always check if the remittance company is licensed by searching their name on Monetary Authority of Singapore’s website at https://eservices.mas.gov.sg/fid. It is not safe to engage unlicensed remittance agents such as hawala or hundi brokers, as they may run away with your money. If you are unable to send money home on your own, you can ask your employer for assistance.

question: Who can help me if I cannot remit money back home?
ground_truth: If you are unable to send money home on your own, ask your employer to assist you. Your employer must show you proof of the successful remittance transaction. It is not safe to carry large amounts of cash in crowded public places. Do not engage unlicensed remittance agents such as hawala or hundi brokers as they may run away with your money.
answer: If you are unable to remit money home on your own, you have a few options. Firstly, you can ask your employer for assistance. However, your employer must show you proof of the successful remittance transaction. Secondly, if you face financial difficulties, you can approach the Migrant Workers’ Centre (MWC) at 6536 2692 for advice. They may be able to help you find a solution or provide assistance with remitting money home. Lastly, you could discuss your situation with friends or family members who might be able to help or offer guidance. It is important not to resort to unlicensed remittance agents or moneylenders as they may run away with your money and there are penalties for engaging in such activities.

question: If I am sick, what doctor can I go to?
ground_truth:
You may go to any healthcare providers under the Primary Care Plan (PCP). This can be done through telemedicine or by visiting the medical centre itself. You may visit the link to find out which healthcare providers are under the PCP
https://www.mom.gov.sg/primary-care-plan/getting-primary-care-services
answer: If you are a worker in Singapore, you should visit a Singapore-registered doctor or dentist for medical treatment related to your injury or illness. This is because under WICA (Work Injury Compensation Act), only medical expenses incurred from a Singapore-registered healthcare professional are compensated. However, if you do not have a preferred doctor, you can seek assistance from MOM or call 6438 5122 for help in finding one.

question: How to make claims for my workplace injury treatment?
ground_truth:
For temporary incapacity cases - report the accident to your employer and seek compensation for medical leave wages and medical treatment related to the work accident. Temporary incapacity refers to an injured employee being temporarily unable to perform work and earn their usual wages after being placed on medical leave.
For permanent incapacity cases, visit the following link for the steps to make your claim - https://www.mom.gov.sg/workplace-safety-and-health/work-injury-compensation/employees-how-to-claim#report-the-accident-to-employer
answer:
To make a claim for your workplace injury treatment, follow these steps:

1. Inform the Management and Occupational Safety & Health (MOM) about the accident by calling 64385122 or visiting MOM Services Centre at 1500 Bendemeer Road, Singapore 339946. You only need to provide your contact details, the name of your employer and the date of the accident.

2. Remain with your employer as they are required to continue providing you with food and housing while the claim is being processed. If your employer forces you to return to your home country and does not report the accident, call MOM immediately.

3. In case your employer sends you to the airport and forces you to leave Singapore, seek assistance from the officers at the airport immigration counters.

4. Visit a Singapore-registered doctor or dentist for your medical treatment. You can claim compensation for medical expenses under the Work Injury Compensation Act (WICA).

5. Keep records of your correspondence with your supervisor/employer on the work accident details, including any photos taken of the place where you were injured and the tools or machinery that caused your injury. Show these photos to the doctor.

6. Attend all scheduled medical appointments related to your injuries. Failure to do so may result in the suspension of your work injury compensation claim.

7. Keep copies of relevant documents such as medical certificates and medical bills, but hand the originals to your employer. The insurer or MOM will calculate the compensation amount and issue a notice to you and your employer. If there are no objections to the amount, your employer/insurer must pay you within 21 days of the notice service date.

8. You do not need a lawyer to help you with your WICA claim as the compensation amount is based on a fixed formula. More than 75% of WICA claims are settled within eight months from the accident date.

question: How do I renew my work permit?
ground_truth:
To renew your work permit kindly notify your employer 7-12 weeks before the expiry of your work permit. You may visit the link below for more information on renewing your work permit
https://www.mom.gov.sg/passes-and-permits/work-permit-for-foreign-worker/renew-a-work-permit
answer: To renew your work permit, you don't need to take any specific actions as mentioned in the provided context. However, if your employer intends to renew your work permit, they are responsible for paying the renewal fees and not asking you to pay or deduct money from your salary for the renewal costs. If there are any issues with the renewal process, it is recommended that you contact MOM (Ministry of Manpower) directly at 6438 5122 or approach their Services Centre at 1500 Bendemeer Road, Singapore 339946 for assistance.

question: Will I be covered by insurance by my employer?
ground_truth: You will be entitled to medical insurance that is bought by your employer. For more information you may visit the link below - https://www.mom.gov.sg/passes-and-permits/work-permit-for-foreign-worker/sector-specific-rules/medical-insurance
answer: Based on the provided context, there is no explicit mention of whether an employee in Singapore is automatically covered by insurance by their employer. However, employers are responsible for ensuring that employees have medical insurance and are required to pay for any renewal fees associated with it. If you find yourself without medical coverage, you may want to reach out to your employer or MOM Services Centre for assistance. It's essential to review the specific terms of your employment contract regarding health and safety benefits to ensure you understand what is provided.

question: Where are some places I can access support and help?
ground_truth: You can contact the Migrant Workers’ Centre (MWC) at 6536 2692 if you have concerns about employment. You can contact Samaritans of Singapore (SOS) at 1800 2214 444 if you need help for personal issues, counselling for depression or personal issues. You can contact HealthServe at 3138 4443 if you require medical care, counselling or social assistance.  https://www.mom.gov.sg/-/media/mom/documents/publications/mw-guides/mw-handy-guide-english.pdf
answer:
1. Police - Dial 999 for emergencies.
2. Fire / Ambulance Service - Dial 995 for emergencies.
3. Ministry of Manpower - Call at 6438 5122 for assistance.
4. Workplace Safety and Health Council - Call at 6317 1111 for help.
5. Migrant Workers’ Centre - Contact at 6536 2692 or visit their website (www.mlcb.com.sg) if you need any assistance.
6. Samaritans of Singapore (SOS) - Dial 1800 2214 444 for a 24-hour helpline.
7. HealthServe - Contact them at 3138 4443 or their 24-hour helpline.
8. If you are facing employment issues, contact MOM at 6438 5122 for assistance.
9. Approach TADM if you have salary issues. Their location is at MOM Services Centre Level 3, 1500 Bendemeer Road, Singapore 339946.
10. If your employer attempts to send you home forcibly without settling any of your salary, claims or cases, you should approach the officers at the airport immigration counters for assistance. MOM will help you.

question: Where do I go if I need access to legal services?
ground_truth: If you require legal assistance or services, you can contact the Legal Clinic by Migrant Workers’ Centre (MWC) at 6536 2692. If you need further assistance after contacting them, they will arrange a session to meet with you to address your concerns. https://www.mwc.org.sg/how-we-help/legal-clinic
answer: If you need access to legal services, you can contact the Ministry of Law or visit their website for assistance. Alternatively, you may also consider seeking help from legal aid organizations such as the Legal Aid Bureau or the Community Justice Centre, which offer free or subsidized legal advice and representation to eligible individuals.

question: What should I do if my employer deducted my salary?
ground_truth:
Your employer can only deduct due to the following reasons:
You were absent from work without consent
Employer has paid for meals that you requested for
Employer has paid for housing/accommodation, amenities and services that you accepted
Goods or money entrusted to you was lost or damaged
Written consent was given
If none of the reasons fit or have happened, you may report to MOM or the Tripartite Alliance for Dispute Management (TADM). TADM is located at MOM Services Centre.
answer: If your employer makes deductions from your salary, check with your employer what the deduction is for. If the deduction is for any of the costs listed in the provided context (work pass renewal, security bond, medical insurance, repatriation costs, compulsory training, medical fees, or levy payment), report to MOM immediately by calling 6438 5122, or approach MOM Services Centre at 1500 Bendemeer Road, Singapore 339946. If you are unsure about the reason for the deduction, it may be beneficial to discuss this with your employer to clarify the situation.

question: Can I do other jobs if requested by my employer?
ground_truth: You must only work in the occupation and for the employers specified on your work permit card. You are not allowed to work in another occupation even if you are instructed by your employer.
answer: According to the provided context, you are only allowed to work in the occupation and for the employer specified on your work permit card. You are not allowed to work in another occupation even if instructed by your employer.

question: My employer paid me lesser than expected, when I asked him, he said it was used to pay for my meals. What should I do?
ground_truth: you can report to MOM or the Tripartite Alliance for Dispute Management (TADM). TADM is located at MOM Services Centre. Your employer should not be allowed to deduct your salary as per stated in the IPA letter without your consent
answer: If your employer is deducting money from your salary for costs that are listed in the provided context (such as work pass renewal, security bond, medical insurance, repatriation costs, compulsory training, medical fees, or levy payment), report this to MOM immediately by calling 6438 5122 or approaching their Services Centre at 1500 Bendemeer Road, Singapore 339946. If the deduction is not for any of those costs, you may wish to discuss it with your employer first to understand the reason and find a resolution that suits both parties. However, if you feel uncomfortable or unsure, you can still report it to MOM for their assistance.

question: What should I do if I have been involved in a scam?
ground_truth: You may visit this link for assistance if you believe you may have been involved in a scam: https://www.mom.gov.sg/passes-and-permits/work-permit-for-foreign-domestic-worker/publications-and-resources/staying-safe-from-scams
answer:
If you have been involved in a scam, here are some steps you can take:

1. Do not respond to any further communication from the scammers. Ignoring them may prevent them from contacting you again.
2. If they continue to contact you despite your ignoring them, please call the Police at '999' or 1800 255 0000 or inform your employer about the situation.
3. Do not share any personal information such as your name, number, address, bank account details with anyone unless you are sure they are legitimate.
4. If you have shared any sensitive information, contact the relevant authorities to report the incident and take steps to secure your accounts.
5. Keep records of any correspondence or communication related to the scam, as this may be useful for reporting the incident to the appropriate authorities.

question: What are the penalties if I have borrowed money from unlicensed moneylenders?
ground_truth:
"If you have been found to have borrowed money from unlicensed moneylenders, your work permit could be revoked and therefore you will be unable to work in Singapore. The following links contain other relevant legal information regarding the penalties for borrowing money from unlicensed moneylenders: 
https://www.mom.gov.sg/-/media/mom/documents/publications/infocus-monthly-edm/edm-11-police-advisory-on-unlicensed-moneylending-borrowers.pdf 

https://www.mom.gov.sg/-/media/mom/documents/publications/infocus-monthly-edm/edm-20-3-things-to-tell-your-fdw-about-borrowing-singapore.pdf"
answer: If you borrow from unlicensed moneylenders in Singapore, MOM will be informed about your actions and your work permit will be revoked. This means that you will be sent back home and will not be allowed to work in Singapore again. You may also face penalties such as fines and imprisonment if caught engaging with unlicensed remittance agents or moneylenders. It is important to use only licensed online remittance services, mobile apps, and remittance kiosks to avoid such penalties.

question: What should I do if I receive a call or text message from an unfamiliar phone number who says they are from government agencies such as MOM or the police?
ground_truth: Should you receive such a call, it is likely to be a phishing scam whereby someone pretends to be someone they are not in order to access sensitive information such as your bank account details. Do not click on links in unsolicited text messages and emails. If you need to access your bank account, use the official app or type in your bank's web address into your web browser to ensure that you are navigating to the official website. You may visit the following link for more information on how to protect yourself in these situations: https://www.mom.gov.sg/passes-and-permits/work-permit-for-foreign-domestic-worker/publications-and-resources/staying-safe-from-scams
answer:
If you receive a call or text message from an unfamiliar phone number claiming to be from government agencies such as MOM or the police, it is essential to verify their identity. Here's what you can do:

1. Do not provide any sensitive information (e.g., your full name, ID number, bank account details) over the call or text message.
2. Hang up and try to contact the agency directly using the official phone numbers provided in the context information, such as 6438 5122 for MOM or 999 for emergencies.
3. If possible, avoid engaging with them further over the call or text message. Instead, wait for a follow-up call or message from the official number of the agency to confirm their identity and purpose for contacting you.
4. Be cautious about any requests for immediate action or payments. Official agencies will usually not ask for sensitive information or money over phone calls or text messages.
5. If you suspect the call or text message is fraudulent, report it to the authorities or your employer immediately.

question: How can I keep updated with the latest rules and regulations in Singapore?
ground_truth: You may visit official websites such as www.gov.sg and www.mom.gov.sg for the latest updates to the rules and regulations in Singapore. Alternatively you may access the myMOM portal for regular updates as well.
answer:

1. Do not provide any sensitive information (e.g., your full name, ID number, bank account details) over the call or text message.
2. Hang up and try to contact the agency directly using the official phone numbers provided in the context information, such as 6438 5122 for MOM or 999 for emergencies.
3. If possible, avoid engaging with them further over the call or text message. Instead, wait for a follow-up call or message from the official number of the agency to confirm their identity and purpose for contacting you.
4. Be cautious about any requests for immediate action or payments. Official agencies will usually not ask for sensitive information or money over phone calls or text messages.
5. If you suspect the call or text message is fraudulent, report it to the authorities or your employer immediately.

question: Where can I go for help if I have financial difficulties?
ground_truth:
You may visit the following channels if you are facing financial difficulties. 
Credit Counselling Singapore: 6225-5227 (www.ccs.org.sg) 
National Council on Problem Gambling: 1800-6-668-668 (www.ncpg.org.sg) 
ComCare: 1800-222-0000 (www.msf.gov.sg/comcare)

question: What happens if I am caught littering?
ground_truth: If you are caught littering, you will be fined $300 for the first offence and $600 per offence thereafter
answer: If you are caught littering in Singapore, you may face a fine of up to $2,000, with increased fines for repeat offenders.

question: Are there restrictions on drinking alcohol outside?
ground_truth:
You may buy and drink alcohol outside anytime except for the hours between 10:30pm to 7am daily. You may visit this link for more information on the matter: https://www.mha.gov.sg/docs/default-source/media-room-doc/annexestothepressreleaseonfirstreadingofliquorcontrolsupplyandconsumptionbill.pdf?sfvrsn=d9df36e2_0#:~:text=Under%20the%20new%20Bill%2C%20the,of%20liquor%20in%20public%20places.

https://www.3mk.sg/blogs/three-musketeers-liquor-blog/drinking-laws-in-singapore-2023
answer: Yes, in Singapore, there are restrictions on drinking alcohol outside. This applies especially during prohibited hours and in public areas that are not licensed outlets like coffee shops. Drinking alcohol outside these venues is against the law. For more information about the liquor laws, please visit [www.mha.gov.sg](http://www.mha.gov.sg).

question: How to help my friend who got scammed?
ground_truth: You may visit the Ant-Scam Resource Guide for information or access scamshield on how to get help for people who have been scammed
answer: If your friend has been scammed, advise them to approach the police immediately by calling '999' or 1800 255 0000. They should also inform their employer about the situation. Additionally, they can seek help from the Migrant Workers’ Centre (MWC) at 6536 2692 for further assistance. It is crucial that they do not respond to any messages or offers from unlicensed moneylenders, as this may be considered involvement in their illegal activities. If your friend continues to engage with unlicensed moneylenders, their work permit may be revoked and they will not be allowed to work in Singapore again.

question: How can I go around Singapore by myself?
ground_truth: You may use the ez-link card to take bus or the train (MRT). These can be purchased from convenience stores like 7-11 or the MRT stations and you can top up your card using the machines at the MRT stations. For more information you may refer to this link: https://www.mom.gov.sg/-/media/mom/documents/publications/mw-guides/mw-handy-guide-english.pdf
answer:
To travel independently in Singapore, you can use several types of public transport such as buses, Mass Rapid Transit (MRT), Light Rail Transit (LRT), taxis, and private hire vehicles. Here's how to do it with an EZ-Link card:

1. Purchase an EZ-Link card at MRT stations or bus interchanges. This card will allow you to travel by bus, MRT, and LRT.

2. Top up your EZ-Link card at ticket machines located at MRT stations and bus interchanges. You can top up using your bank ATM card.

3. Details of bus and train routes and fares are displayed at bus stops, MRT, and LRT stations.

4. When traveling on buses or trains, be considerate to fellow passengers: queue up while waiting to board, give up your seat to someone who needs it more, move in when standing, let others alight before boarding, and put your bag down so that others have more room to move.
